title: The twins who tricked the Maya gods of death - Ilan Stavans

multiple-choice.question: What activity did the twin brothers, Jun and Wuqub, engage in that disturbed the lords of the underworld?

options.label: A
options.text: They were playing a musical instrument.

options.label: B
options.text: They were playing a game of hide and seek.

options.label: C
options.text: They were running back and forth playing ball.

options.label: D
options.text: They were having a loud argument.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to Jun's head after he was killed by the lords of the underworld?

options.label: A
options.text: It was buried in a grave.

options.label: B
options.text: It was hung from a tree as a trophy.

options.label: C
options.text: It was thrown into a river.

options.label: D
options.text: It was given to his brother Wuqub.

multiple-choice.question: How did Jun's skull impregnate the lord's daughter?

options.label: A
options.text: She touched it and became pregnant.

options.label: B
options.text: It spat on her hand and impregnated her.

options.label: C
options.text: She ate a fruit from the tree where the skull was hung.

options.label: D
options.text: She drank water from a magical spring.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the twin sons born to the lord's daughter?

options.label: A
options.text: Junajpu and Ixb'alanke.

options.label: B
options.text: Wuqub and Jun.

options.label: C
options.text: K'awiil and Hun-Came.

options.label: D
options.text: Ah Puch and Chaac.

multiple-choice.question: What challenge did the lords of the underworld issue to Junajpu and Ixb'alanke?

options.label: A
options.text: A game of chess.

options.label: B
options.text: A game of ball.

options.label: C
options.text: A wrestling match.

options.label: D
options.text: A singing competition.

multiple-choice.question: What obstacle did the twins face in the House of Darkness?

options.label: A
options.text: They had to navigate through a maze.

options.label: B
options.text: They had to climb a steep mountain.

options.label: C
options.text: They had to return a torch unburnt or face death.

options.label: D
options.text: They had to cross a river filled with scorpions.

multiple-choice.question: How did the twins survive the House of Cold?

options.label: A
options.text: They used their magical powers to warm themselves.

options.label: B
options.text: They lit a fire.

options.label: C
options.text: They wore warm clothing.

options.label: D
options.text: They drank hot chocolate.

multiple-choice.question: What happened to Junajpu's head in the House of Bats?

options.label: A
options.text: It was bitten off by a bat.

options.label: B
options.text: It was cut off by a knife.

options.label: C
options.text: It was smashed by a rock.

options.label: D
options.text: It was hidden in a basket.

multiple-choice.question: How did the twins ultimately defeat the lords of the underworld?

options.label: A
options.text: They won the game of ball.

options.label: B
options.text: They killed the lords one by one while disguised as children.

options.label: C
options.text: They used their magical powers to destroy the underworld.

options.label: D
options.text: They enlisted the help of a powerful ally.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of the twins' curse on the lords of the underworld?

options.label: A
options.text: The lords gained more power over the surface world.

options.label: B
options.text: The lords were forced to make sacrifices to the twins.

options.label: C
options.text: The lords lost their power over the surface world and would receive no sacrifices.

options.label: D
options.text: The lords were turned into animals.

title: The sleep disorder you might not know you have - Alayna Vaughan

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of snoring?

options.label: A
options.text: The muscles around the respiratory tract tensing up during sleep.

options.label: B
options.text: The muscles around the respiratory tract relaxing during sleep.

options.label: C
options.text: Congestion in the nasal passages.

options.label: D
options.text: Anatomical features of the respiratory tract.

multiple-choice.question: What is obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: A sleep disorder characterized by pauses in breathing during sleep due to blockages in the airway.

options.label: B
options.text: A sleep disorder characterized by pauses in breathing during sleep due to the brain's failure to regulate breathing.

options.label: C
options.text: A sleep disorder characterized by excessive snoring.

options.label: D
options.text: A sleep disorder characterized by insomnia.

multiple-choice.question: What is central sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: A sleep disorder characterized by pauses in breathing during sleep due to blockages in the airway.

options.label: B
options.text: A sleep disorder characterized by pauses in breathing during sleep due to the brain's failure to regulate breathing.

options.label: C
options.text: A sleep disorder characterized by excessive snoring.

options.label: D
options.text: A sleep disorder characterized by insomnia.

multiple-choice.question: What are some common symptoms of obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: Headaches, decreased concentration, and chronic fatigue.

options.label: B
options.text: Insomnia, sleepwalking, and nightmares.

options.label: C
options.text: Snoring, sleep talking, and sleep paralysis.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What are some risk factors for developing obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: Larger tongues, thicker necks, and smaller jaws.

options.label: B
options.text: Older age, weight gain, and drinking alcohol before sleep.

options.label: C
options.text: Smoking, high blood pressure, and diabetes.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is a common treatment for obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: Surgery to remove excess tissue in the airway.

options.label: B
options.text: CPAP machines that deliver a constant stream of pressurized air.

options.label: C
options.text: Oral appliances that advance the position of the jaw.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated percentage of people with obstructive sleep apnea who are unaware they have the condition?
What can happen to the body when it experiences periods of low oxygen intake due to obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: The body releases stress hormones and blood vessels constrict.

options.label: B
options.text: The body releases relaxation hormones and blood vessels dilate.

options.label: C
options.text: The body experiences no significant changes.

options.label: D
options.text: The body goes into a state of hibernation.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential consequence of untreated obstructive sleep apnea?

options.label: A
options.text: Hypertension and cardiovascular problems.

options.label: B
options.text: Insomnia and sleepwalking.

options.label: C
options.text: Snoring and sleep talking.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

multiple-choice.question: What can help alleviate obstructive sleep apnea in some cases?

options.label: A
options.text: Weight loss and behavioral shifts such as limiting alcohol consumption before bed.

options.label: B
options.text: Surgery to remove excess tissue in the airway.

options.label: C
options.text: CPAP machines that deliver a constant stream of pressurized air.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

title: 3 secrets of resilient people - Lucy Hone

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's primary area of research and expertise?

options.label: A
options.text: Grief and bereavement

options.label: B
options.text: Resilience and mental fitness

options.label: C
options.text: Social psychology and group dynamics

options.label: D
options.text: Clinical psychology and mental illness

multiple-choice.question: What event in the speaker's life led her to re-evaluate her approach to resilience and grief?

options.label: A
options.text: The death of her mother

options.label: B
options.text: The death of her 12-year-old daughter Abi

options.label: C
options.text: A serious illness or injury

options.label: D
options.text: A major life change or transition

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the primary problem with the traditional approach to grief and bereavement?

options.label: A
options.text: It is too focused on the individual and neglects the role of social support

options.label: B
options.text: It is too focused on the negative emotions and neglects the importance of positive emotions

options.label: C
options.text: It leaves people feeling like victims and powerless to exert influence over their grieving process

options.label: D
options.text: It is too rigid and does not allow for individual differences in the grieving process

multiple-choice.question: What is the first strategy for resilience discussed by the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Focusing on the positive emotions and experiences

options.label: B
options.text: Practicing gratitude and appreciation

options.label: C
options.text: Recognizing that suffering is a part of life and that adversity does not discriminate

options.label: D
options.text: Developing a growth mindset and learning from failures

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of "benefit finding" in psychology, as discussed by the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: The process of identifying and focusing on the negative consequences of a traumatic event

options.label: B
options.text: The process of identifying and focusing on the positive consequences or benefits of a traumatic event

options.label: C
options.text: The process of denying or avoiding the negative emotions associated with a traumatic event

options.label: D
options.text: The process of blaming others or external circumstances for a traumatic event

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the result of practicing gratitude and focusing on the positive emotions and experiences?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased stress and anxiety

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased happiness and well-being

options.label: C
options.text: Increased gratitude, happiness, and well-being, and decreased depression

options.label: D
options.text: No significant impact on mental health or well-being

multiple-choice.question: What is the third strategy for resilience discussed by the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Practicing mindfulness and presence

options.label: B
options.text: Developing a growth mindset and learning from failures

options.label: C
options.text: Asking oneself if their thoughts and actions are helping or harming them

options.label: D
options.text: Focusing on the negative emotions and experiences

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the primary benefit of asking oneself if their thoughts and actions are helping or harming them?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows individuals to avoid taking responsibility for their actions

options.label: B
options.text: It allows individuals to blame others or external circumstances for their problems

options.label: C
options.text: It gives individuals control over their decision-making and allows them to make intentional choices

options.label: D
options.text: It has no significant impact on mental health or well-being

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main message about resilience?

options.label: A
options.text: Resilience is a fixed trait that some people have and others do not

options.label: B
options.text: Resilience is a complex and elusive concept that is difficult to understand or develop

options.label: C
options.text: Resilience requires extraordinary processes and is only available to a select few

options.label: D
options.text: Resilience requires ordinary processes and is available to anyone who is willing to try

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the primary takeaway from her experience and research on resilience?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is impossible to live and grieve at the same time

options.label: B
options.text: That resilience is only available to those who have experienced trauma or adversity

options.label: C
options.text: That thinking in a certain way can help individuals navigate tough times and build resilience

options.label: D
options.text: That resilience is a fixed trait that cannot be developed or improved

title: The secrets of the worldâ€™s most famous symphony - Hanako Sawada

multiple-choice.question: Who composed the Symphony Number Five that premiered in 1808?

options.label: A
options.text: Ludwig van Mozart

options.label: B
options.text: Ludwig van Beethoven

options.label: C
options.text: Haydn

options.label: D
options.text: Bach

multiple-choice.question: What was unique about Beethoven's career as a composer?

options.label: A
options.text: He composed music exclusively for religious functions.

options.label: B
options.text: He was one of the first freelance composers, making a living by composing and selling his music.

options.label: C
options.text: He only composed music for private events held by wealthy patrons.

options.label: D
options.text: He was a composer and a performer.

multiple-choice.question: What style of composition did Beethoven experiment with in his Fifth Symphony?

options.label: A
options.text: Classical style

options.label: B
options.text: Romanticism

options.label: C
options.text: Baroque style

options.label: D
options.text: Impressionism

multiple-choice.question: What is the "fate motif" in Beethoven's Fifth Symphony?

options.label: A
options.text: A rhythmic pattern of four equal notes

options.label: B
options.text: A rhythmic pattern of three short notes followed by a lingering fourth note

options.label: C
options.text: A melodic pattern of descending arpeggios

options.label: D
options.text: A harmonic progression from C minor to C major

multiple-choice.question: What instruments did Beethoven use in his Fifth Symphony that were not commonly used in classical compositions?

options.label: A
options.text: Trombones, piccolo, and contrabassoon

options.label: B
options.text: Drums, trumpet, and French horn

options.label: C
options.text: Violin, viola, and cello

options.label: D
options.text: Piano, harp, and guitar

multiple-choice.question: What is the emotional arc of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony?

options.label: A
options.text: From joyful to somber

options.label: B
options.text: From somber to triumphant

options.label: C
options.text: From calm to agitated

options.label: D
options.text: From happy to sad

multiple-choice.question: What personal challenge was Beethoven facing while composing his Fifth Symphony?

options.label: A
options.text: He was struggling with poverty.

options.label: B
options.text: He was battling with hearing loss.

options.label: C
options.text: He was dealing with the loss of a loved one.

options.label: D
options.text: He was facing criticism from his peers.

multiple-choice.question: How did the Allies use Beethoven's Fifth Symphony during World War II?

options.label: A
options.text: As a symbol of defeat

options.label: B
options.text: As a code for victory

options.label: C
options.text: As a call to arms

options.label: D
options.text: As a tribute to the fallen

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Morse code connection to Beethoven's Fifth Symphony?

options.label: A
options.text: The fate motif sounds out the letter V in Morse code.

options.label: B
options.text: The fate motif sounds out the letter B in Morse code.

options.label: C
options.text: The symphony's title is encoded in Morse code.

options.label: D
options.text: The composer's name is encoded in Morse code.

multiple-choice.question: What is the overall effect of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony on its listeners?

options.label: A
options.text: It takes them on a journey of suspense and revelation, ultimately guiding them into the light.

options.label: B
options.text: It leaves them feeling somber and defeated.

options.label: C
options.text: It inspires them to take action.

options.label: D
options.text: It calms their minds and soothes their souls.

title: The simplest math problem no one can solve

multiple-choice.question: What is the Collatz Conjecture?

options.label: A
options.text: A mathematical problem that states that every positive integer will eventually end up in a loop of 4, 2, 1 when applying the rules of 3x+1.

options.label: B
options.text: A mathematical problem that states that every positive integer will eventually end up in a loop of 1, 2, 4 when applying the rules of 3x+1.

options.label: C
options.text: A mathematical problem that states that every positive integer will eventually end up in a loop of 2, 4, 8 when applying the rules of 3x+1.

options.label: D
options.text: A mathematical problem that states that every positive integer will eventually end up in a loop of 1, 3, 9 when applying the rules of 3x+1.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the mathematician who is considered the world authority on 3x+1?

options.label: A
options.text: Jeffrey Lagarias

options.label: B
options.text: Paul Erdos

options.label: C
options.text: Luther Collatz

options.label: D
options.text: Terry Tao

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the numbers that are obtained by applying the rules of 3x+1?

options.label: A
options.text: Hailstone numbers

options.label: B
options.text: Collatz numbers

options.label: C
options.text: 3x+1 numbers

options.label: D
options.text: Lagarias numbers

multiple-choice.question: What is the pattern that is observed in the leading digits of the numbers in the 3x+1 sequence?

options.label: A
options.text: Benford's law

options.label: B
options.text: The normal distribution

options.label: C
options.text: The uniform distribution

options.label: D
options.text: The exponential distribution

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of Terry Tao's proof regarding the Collatz Conjecture?

options.label: A
options.text: He proved that the Collatz Conjecture is true.

options.label: B
options.text: He proved that the Collatz Conjecture is false.

options.label: C
options.text: He proved that almost all numbers have a number in their sequence that is arbitrarily small.

options.label: D
options.text: He proved that all numbers have a number in their sequence that is arbitrarily small.

multiple-choice.question: What is the possible reason why mathematicians have not been able to prove the Collatz Conjecture?

options.label: A
options.text: The conjecture is false.

options.label: B
options.text: The conjecture is undecidable.

options.label: C
options.text: The conjecture is too difficult to prove.

options.label: D
options.text: The conjecture is too easy to prove.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the mathematical machine created by John Conway that is related to the Collatz Conjecture?

options.label: A
options.text: FRACTRAN

options.label: B
options.text: COLLATZ

options.label: D
options.text: HAILSTONE

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of applying the rules of 3x+1 to negative numbers?

options.label: A
options.text: There is only one loop.

options.label: B
options.text: There are two loops.

options.label: C
options.text: There are three loops.

options.label: D
options.text: There are no loops.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the process of applying the rules of 3x+1 to a number?

options.label: A
options.text: Iteration

options.label: B
options.text: Recursion

options.label: C
options.text: Looping

options.label: D
options.text: Cycling

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the sponsor of the video?

options.label: A
options.text: Brilliant

options.label: B
options.text: Veritasium

options.label: C
options.text: 3Blue1Brown

options.label: D
options.text: Khan Academy
